But behind the scenes, the league is in the middle of an experiment that could change the way the game is played at the highest level.
As part of a three-year agreement with Major League Baseball, the Atlantic League is testing out a series of rule changes to speed up the game, make it safer for players and give it more action.
Some changes, like decreasing the amount of time between innings, are small, while others, like letting batters steal first on any wild pitch and having a radar-tracked strike zone are revolutionary.
And they come as baseball is in a demographic crisis, with 9% of Americans listing it as their favorite sport to watch according to a Gallup poll released in 2018.
Baseball has tended to skew older in terms of its following, and this group of owners and the commissioner would like to see it start to skew younger.
That's Rick White, president of the Atlantic League.
Of all the changes, the radar-tracked strike zone is probably the most eye-catching.
It uses what's called the Automated Ball-Strike System to determine each hitter's strike zone and communicate whether a ball is inside or outside via an earpiece to the home plate umpire.
It all stems from what White says is a constant pressure for accuracy in equity.
Everyone in professional sports, but especially Major League Baseball, wants to create fairness and objectivity as opposed to a disparity between one player or another or their performance.
Bees manager Mauro Gozzo is against some of the rule changes, but he likes the radar-tracked strike zones.
Dealing with the grab bag of different strike zones is an everyday struggle for him as a manager.
